awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Exploring the physics of galaxy clusters with comprehensive cosmological simulations
awd_abstract_narration:
Galaxy clusters are some of the largest known structures in the universe. Modeling their growth over the age of the universe will give us insight on how matter, energy, and the laws of physics influence the universe that we see today. This project will add some more details to the computer modeling to provide better approximations to the physics governing the behavior of the gas in galaxy clusters. The results of these new models will be simulations that can be used by other researchers who are studying galaxies and galaxy clusters.

Galaxy clusters are some of the largest structures in the universe. Modeling their growth over cosmological time scales gives us insight on how dark matter, ordinary matter, and the laws of physics influence the universe that we see today. The proposed project will add more detailed physics in the form of magnetic fields, anisotropic thermal conduction, and radiative feedback from active galactic nuclei (AGN). The project will use a moving mesh code known as AREPO to perform these simulations. The simulations will follow the IllustrisTNG cosmological models with the added physics. Zoom-ins of clusters will be used to compare the effects of the new physics models and to make observational predictions for future ground and space-based observatories. At the end of the project, the data and simulations will be made publicly available.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
We live in a galaxy that is one of countless in the known universe.  These galaxies are made up of dark matter, stars, and gas that interact with each other.  These interactions are difficult to study since they happen on massive scales and lightyears away.  Galaxy simulations are a key method for understanding and building models for these interactions since they allow us to directly test our predictions.  In our work, we use simulations to understand galaxy clusters, which are groups of hundreds to thousands of galaxies and contain extreme physics like hot gas, large magnetic fields, and supermassive black holes.


To make full use of simulations, we must be able to compare results from simulations to observations of the real universe.  As part of this work, we constructed "mock observations" to produce data that can be directly compared to observations from telescopes.  These mock observations were introduced through the MOCK-X analysis framework software, so properties of galaxy clusters, like X-ray emission or luminosity, can be easily calculated from simulations.  We then used this framework to test the methods commonly used to measure the mass of galaxy clusters and showed that high-mass galaxy clusters are associated with a much larger bias in these measurements.


We also investigated the categorization of galaxy clusters.  Clusters that are undergoing dynamical and morphological changes are generally classified as unrelaxed while clusters that are more static are classified as relaxed.  Relaxed clusters are often used in studies since their properties can be more accurately derived, but it is difficult to determine when a cluster can be considered relaxed.  We explored nine commonly used criteria for classifying a cluster as relaxed and showed that these criteria do not produce consistent samples of galaxy clusters.  Therefore, any study that makes use of these criteria is subject to a non-trivial, poorly understood selection bias.


Finally, we investigated methods for measuring the size of galaxy clusters.  Galaxy clusters are not distinct objects but, rather, are embedded within a web-like structure containing all the matter in the universe.  Knowing their size is fundamental to a broad range of studies, like understanding the evolution of the universe or how galaxies evolve in different ecosystems.  A promising size definition, called the "splashback radius", defines a galaxy clusters size by identifying the region of space that is dominated by the clusters orbital dynamics.  This can be identified using features in the measured density of the cluster.  However, the density of the cluster is dominated by dark matter, which is not visible using telescopes.  In our work, we tested measurements of the splashback radius using the gas and galaxy densities to establish their potential as tracers of the splashback radius in dark matter.  We find that, overall, measurements using the gas and galaxies follow the same trends as when measured using dark matter in simulations.  Thus, we expect that these components can be used to observationally measure the splashback radius in galaxy clusters, but there is still work to be done to understand the associated biases.
